longest_values: Commencing as of March 15, 2001, the Law Department (Department) and Department of Sanitation (DSNY) retained the services of the law firm Hawkins, Delafield  and  Wood, LLP (Hawkins), to provide legal services in connection with the implementation of the Citys approved Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan for the period of 2006 - 2025 (the SWMP).  Services under the contract included development and drafting of procurement documents relating to solid waste management; development, drafting and negotiating contracts, leases and memoranda of understanding relating to solid waste management; researching and providing advice on solid waste management issues relating to environmental law, real property law, contract law, land use law and tax law; and providing legal advice on public/private project-development financial models and/or alternatives relating to long-term solid waste management.  The initial end date of the contract was March 14, 2006.  That end date was extended to March 14, 2007, pursuant to PPB Rules § 4-02(b)(1)(iii).  The end date was further extended to March 14, 2010 by entering into a Negotiated Acquisition Extension Contract with Hawkins, pursuant to PPB Rules § 3-04(b)(2)(iii).  Effective March 15, 2010, the Department entered into a Negotiated Acquisition Second Extension Contract with Hawkins, pursuant to PPB Rules § 3-04(b)(2)(iii) so that Hawkins could continue working on the same issues for DSNY through March 14, 2013.  It is currently estimated that in order to complete performance of the original scope of services, the Hawkins contract must be extended for a third time, with the term of the third extension contract, pursuant to PPB Rules § 3-04(b)(2)(iii), through June 30, 2015.  During the three year extension period from March 2010 through March 2013, Hawkins has provided invaluable services to DSNY on many projects that DSNY continues to advance pursuant to the SWMP. Specifically, Hawkins was instrumental in the finalization of a long-term (20-year) intergovernmental agreement with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for the use of its Essex County Resource Recovery Facility, New Jersey. The negotiation period, extended and complicated by a change in the PAs facility operator, resulted in contract registration in August 2012 and the start of services in October 2012. Hawkins also drafted the Contract Principles and business terms for the RFP for New and Emerging Solid Waste Management Technology issued by DSNY in 2012 and provided legal support during the proposal evaluation phase. Hawkins has also negotiated and drafted five substantive Contract Memoranda during this time period: 1) for the Long-Term Staten Island Service Contract (SI Contract) to allow leases for unneeded equipment to be relinquished, reducing the Contract Amount and saving the City approximately $18.6 million; 2) for the Long-Term Brooklyn Service Contract (Brooklyn Contract) to allow for a food waste pilot; and 3) for line haul carrier reprocurements or contract extensions for the Long-Term Bronx, Brooklyn and Staten Island Contracts. Hawkins has also worked on uncontrollable circumstance claims made or raised for these three Long-Term Contracts related to railroad bridge failures, railroad strikes and Sandy-related service issues. Hawkins worked on the development of a Service Contract in 2009 for the commercial waste export facility to be developed at the West 59th Street Marine Transfer Station before that project was put on hold in anticipation of the start of operations for the New Gansevoort MTS.   Notwithstanding the work done on these other DSNY projects and contracts, the vast majority of the work done by Hawkins has been on the Marine Transfer Station RFP  the negotiation of contracts for the transport and disposal of waste from four Marine Transfer Stations (MTSs). During the last three years, both technical/price and price Best and Final Offer (BAFO) processes were undertaken and resulted in the review and clarification of proposals submitted by three of the four vendors selected for contract discussions and the negotiation, led by Hawkins, of three service contracts simultaneously. As a result of the price only BAFO, contract negotiations have advanced with two of the four vendors on the Contract for MSW Management, Transportation and Disposal Services for the North Shore and E. 91st Street MTSs, now finalized and pending award, and the Contract for MSW Management, Transportation and Disposal Services for the Southwest Brooklyn and Hamilton Avenue MTSs, in the final stage of negotiations.  During the extension period, the long-term contracts that Hawkins will assist DSNY in negotiating and finalizing include a long-term contract with a privately owned transfer station operator in Queens and the finalization and award of the above-described Contract for MSW Management, Transportation and Disposal Services for the Southwest Brooklyn and Hamilton Avenue MTSs.  These contracts share many similarities with the contract for the Long-Term Staten Island, Bronx and Brooklyn Contracts handled by Hawkins under the initial term of the contract and the subsequent Negotiated Acquisition and extension work and rely on Hawkins expertise on the legal issues.  DSNY will also require the services of Hawkins for the potential use of the existing 59th Street MTS as a facility where private firms may export commercial waste, as well as the use of the former Gansevoort MTS as a facility for the barge export of recyclables collected in Manhattan. Furthermore, pursuant to the SWMP, DSNY may require the services of Hawkins in connection with the drafting and negotiation of contracts to implement the New and Emerging Solid Waste Management Technologies procurement for the management of a portion of the Citys waste.

VENDOR SOURCE ID: 75955  BID DOCUMENTS ARE AVAILABLE AT: http://www.nyc.gov/buildnyc This bid solicitation includes M/WBE Participation Goal(s) for subcontracted work. For the MWBE goals, please visit our website at www.nyc.gov/buildnyc see Bid Opportunities. For more information about MWBE certification, please call 311 or go to www.nyc.gov/getcertified  THE CITY OF NEW YORK DEPARTMENT OF DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION INFRASTRUCTURE DIVISION  SPECIAL NOTICE TO BIDDERS II LEAD PROJECT ID: MED609-INSTALLATION OF 48-INCH, 36-INCH, 20-INCH AND 12-INCH WATER MAINS FOR SHAFTS 24B, 25B, 27B AND 30B INCLUDING SEWER, WATER MAIN, HIGHWAY, STREET LIGHTING AND TRAFFIC SIGNAL WORK TOGETHER WITH ALL WORK INCIDENTAL THERETO - BOROUGH OF MANHATTAN CITY OF NEW YORK  The Agency received information that a City-certified M/WBE construction firm had concerns that the subcontractor participation goal (1.5 percent ) established for this contract was unduly low. In the view of the M/WBE Company making this inquiry, the prime contractor would be a construction manager, and as such, would use many subcontractors, potentially generating more opportunities for qualified M/WBEs.   The Agency has reviewed the participation goal for this procurement and has determined that the percentage stated in the bid solicitation is appropriate under Local Law 129 of 2005, which is the authorizing legislation that established the Citys M/WBE program and that sets the terms under which subcontractor participation goals may be imposed on City agency contracts. The Agency has reached this conclusion based on the following reasons:    Under Local Law 129, subcontractor participation goals may lawfully be applied to individual contracts only in a specified manner.  The Agency may apply its participation goal only to first-tier subcontracts, not to the additional subcontracts that may be awarded under those subcontracts.  The Agency must also limit the application of any participation goal to subcontracts that are anticipated to be valued below one million dollars.  Where a prime contract is expected to generate subcontracts valued in amounts that equal or exceed one million dollars, no participation goal can be applied to those larger subcontracts.  For the type of work solicited in this bid, while construction managers would be eligible to bid, the Agencys records indicate that historically most bidders for similar work have been general contractors.  The Agencys records further indicate that in the heavy construction industry, prime contractors typically perform a significant amount of the contract work directly, i.e., with lower subcontracting levels than may occur in other types of construction.  Moreover, based on the nature and scale of this prime contract, the Agencys records indicate that many of the subcontracts that may be let by the prime vendor will be awarded at values that substantially exceed one million dollars, and thus would not fall within the range that the Agency can lawfully consider in establishing the contracts Local Law 129 participation goal.    Because this bid solicitation covers the public work only, and is not a joint bid procurement that would also include public utility work, the Agency cannot consider any of the subcontracts for such utility work in setting the subcontractor participation goal for this contract.    This bid solicitation is advertised with an anticipated value of over $200 million.  By estimating the target subcontracting percentage for this contract as 3 percent , the Agency is indicating that it anticipates approximately six million dollars worth of small (under one million dollars) subcontracts for that $200 million prime contract.  If the bids come in at $300 million, that value would be nine million dollars, and at $400 million, twelve million dollars, and so on.  While the applicable citywide M/WBE subcontractor participation goals for construction work total 31 percent , in this case the Agency has set the subcontractor participation goal for this specific contract at 50 percent .  However, under Local Law 129, the 50 percent  participation goal can only be lawfully applied to the 3 percent  of contract value estimated to be comprised of subcontracts valued below one million dollars.  The Agencys records of past similar contracts indicate that it is unlikely that any larger proportion of small subcontracts would be awarded: most of the first-tier subcontracts on this contract are likely to significantly exceed the one million dollar benchmark of Local Law 129.   While the Agency thus does not have a basis to set a higher target subcontracting percentage or participation goal for this procurement, the Agency further notes that the City of New York strongly encourages all potential bidders to consult the Citys M/WBE vendor directory  http://mtprawvwsbswtp1-1.nyc.gov/Search.aspx.  There are many City-certified M/WBE firms that are fully qualified to perform a wide range of construction work and associated services that are likely to be used in connection with this contract.  Certified M/WBEs have succeeded in winning and performing on many prime contracts and subcontracts that exceed the one million dollar limit of Local Law 129.  Accordingly, even if the contracts participation goal does not cover larger subcontracts, the Agency encourages prime bidders to consider joint venture and subcontractor relationships with qualified M/WBEs.

The City of New York Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) is the agency responsible for most housing and urban renewal matters, including without limitation, the management, disposition and development of City-owned urban renewal and/or residential properties and the enforcement of compliance with State of New York (State) and City laws, rules and regulations governing residential dwellings in New York City. HPD is responsible for the management of buildings taken In-Rem, for Urban Renewal, or through Condemnation and leases buildings to alternative managers who are then responsible for the management of the buildings. Under HPDs Tenant Interim Lease (TIL) Program, the buildings are leased to tenants associations, which manage the buildings. HPD eventually sells the buildings to the tenants as Housing Development Fund Corporation (HDFC) Co-operatives.    HPD currently maintains a list of contractors (PQL) who conduct work in General Construction (work does not include Wicks Law licensed trades), exclusively for the TIL Program. By establishing contractors qualifications and experience in advance, HPD has developed a pool of competent contractors from which it can draw, to promptly and effectively make needed repairs in buildings directly administered by the TIL Program.  HPD selects contractors from the list for repair and emergency work of up to $100,000 per work order.  As of August 5, 2013, HPD plans to increase the volume of repair and emergency work performed by this PQL by adding the General Construction assignments conducted under HPDs Alternative Enforcement Program (AEP).   AEP, created through Local Law 29 of 2007 and amended by Local Law 7 of 2011, is an enforcement program that enables HPD to identify the most distressed multiple dwellings and ensure that violations and their underlying conditions are corrected.  Each year, HPD designates 200 different multiple dwellings for participation in the AEP.  If the owner fails to comply with the terms of the Law, HPD may hire a contractor to make the necessary repairs.  These repairs, of up to $100,000,  will now be directed through the contractors on the TIL PQL, in addition to the work already provided  under  the TIL Program.  HPD is seeking to evaluate and pre-qualify a list of contractors (PQL) by this application process, to conduct work in General Construction (work will not include Wicks Law licensed trades), exclusively for HPDs Tenant Interim Lease TIL Program. By establishing contractors qualifications and experience in advance, HPD will have a pool of competent contractors from which it can draw to promptly and effectively make needed repairs in buildings directly administered by the TIL Program.  HPD will select contractors from the list for repair and emergency work of up to $100,000 per work order.  HPD separately maintains lists of Prequalified Vendors who perform work in various trades under its Emergency Repair Program (ERP).  While the work performed by vendors in the trades associated with this current list may be very similar or the same as work under the TIL Program, these current lists are separate and distinct from this proposed TIL PQL for General Construction.  Vendors who are currently on the ERP Lists and who meet the criteria indicated herein are strongly encouraged to apply for inclusion on the TIL PQL for General Construction.  Vendors are also advised that solicitations for work under the TIL and AEP Programs will be issued as separate and distinct work orders from ERP and will be clearly identified as TIL or AEP work.  HPD will consider only those applications for the TIL Pre-qualified Lists that meet any one of the following criteria:  1.	The submitting entity must be a Minority and Women-owned Business Enterprise certified by the New York City Department of Small Business Services (New York City-certified M/WBE).  2.	The submitting entity must have entered into a qualified joint venture agreement between one or more New York City-certified M/WBEs, in which the certified firm(s) is entitled or exposed to at least 25 percent  of the total profit or loss.  3.	The submitting entity must agree to sub-contract no less than 50 percent  of any awarded job to a New York City-certified M/WBE for each and every work order awarded.   *Firms that are in the process of becoming a New York City-certified M/WBE may submit a PQL application and submit an M/WBE Acknowledgement Letter, which states the Department of Small Business Services has begun the Certification process.  HPD will hold a pre-submission conference for potential applicants at 10:00 a.m. on June 20, 2013 at HPD, 100 Gold Street, Room 6S, New York, NY 10038. Potential applicants, though not required to attend the conference in order to apply for inclusion on the list, are encouraged to do so.  Application documents may also be obtained on-line at http//a856internet.nyc.gov/nycvendoronline/home.html. or at www.nyc.gov/hpd

The Comptroller of the City of New York, acting on behalf of the New York City Retirement Systems (the Systems), is issuing this Request for Proposals (RFP) to identify and select investment advisors to create and manage U.S. and Global Convertible Bond Portfolios for the Systems.   Contract(s) resulting from this RFP will be for a term of three years with renewal options for up to six additional years at the discretion of the Comptroller.    Minimum requirements include:  1.	Required Investment Approach  The proposed product must be a Convertible Bond product that is benchmarked to a major market index of Convertible Bond securities, such as the Merrill Lynch All U.S. Convertibles Index or its equivalent.  Note:  The benchmark(s) to be used for each Systems portfolio(s) will be determined by the Comptrollers Office as part of the development of Investment Guidelines, with consideration for each Systems requirements.   Proposals for the following products utilizing convertible securities will be considered non-responsive: 1) convertible arbitrage, 2) long/short, 3) any other products utilizing leverage, 4) fixed income or equity strategies that do not primarily invest in convertibles, 5) products based on derivative strategies and 6) retail products.  2.	Assets under Management  At a minimum, as of December 31, 2006, the proposer must:  a.	Have at least $100 million under management in institutional Convertible Bond Securities products.  In determining total assets for this requirement, the proposer may only include assets of institutional separate accounts and institutional commingled funds; mutual funds may also be included if they are managed similarly to the proposers tax-exempt accounts; and  b.	Provide a three year return composite for the proposed product (as of December 31, 2006); proposers with longer records must provide that record since inception.  Performance must be calculated in accordance with CFA Institute Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) - required methodologies, which refer to both the calculation of returns and the creation and maintenance of the composite, with a composite market value of at least $100 million; and  c.	Have at least one non-affiliated institutional client with assets of at least $25 million in the proposed product;  Note:  Do not combine assets from distinct Convertible Bond products with carve-outs of Convertible Bond securities from other products to calculate total Convertible assets.  Convertible assets that are carved out from other portfolios will not be considered toward the minimum requirements.  3.	Performance Track Record  A proposer must provide descriptive and statistical evidence of experience managing portfolios in accordance with the particular style of management it proposes.  Additionally:  a.	Proposers must have, at a minimum, a live three-year track record managing the proposed product for the period ending December 31, 2006, calculated in accordance with GIPS-required methodologies.  b.	Only proposers who demonstrate a continuous track record for at least the entire three-year period will be considered.  The following track records will not be considered responsive:  	Linked performance of two different products, even when they both use a similar approach and the same personnel. 	Performance extracted from any other product. 	Back tested or otherwise simulated track record.  c.	Proposers may link track records from two firms if they meet GIPS standards for portability.  The products offered by the two firms must be substantially the same in style and use a similar benchmark. The predecessor firm can not be eligible to submit the same track record.  d.	Do not include securities lending income in the track record.  4.	Regulatory   The proposing firm must have offered a Convertibles product for at least three years as of December 31, 2006 as a registered investment adviser under the Investment Advisors Act of 1940, or as a bank or insurance company.    5.	Ethics Policy Certification  Proposer must certify compliance with the New York City Retirement Systems (NYCRS) Ethics and Compliance Policy by signing the NYCRS Ethics Policy Certification.  These appear in the RFP as Exhibits 3 and 3  A.    The RFP, which fully describes scope of work and proposal submission procedures, will be available for download from the Comptrollers Web site, www.comptroller.nyc.gov, on or about April 5, 2007.  To register to download the RFP, select Asset Management, then RFPs and scroll down to select Register for RFP button.  Questions about the RFP should be transmitted by e-mail to Eric Wollman, Esq., Deputy Director of Asset Management Contracting, at bamcontracts@comptroller.nyc.gov by April 19, 2007 by 4:00 P.M. (ET).

ACS seeks community-based organizations to work with ACS-funded foster care, preventive, and child care/Head Start organizations, as well as ACS child protective staff, as members of coalitions for a demonstration project.  ACS wishes to determine the feasibility and efficiency of a community based approach to childrens services.  ACS believes this approach will lead to services that will be more community-oriented and will tap into the wealth of resources available within the community to help children and their families.    ACS intends to conduct demonstrations in the following 11 different community districts throughout the five boroughs: Mott Haven (Bronx CD 1), Highbridge (Bronx CD 4), Soundview (Bronx CD 9), Bedford-Stuyvesant (Brooklyn CD 3), East New York (Brooklyn CD 5), Bushwick (Brooklyn CD4), Lower East Side (Manhattan CD 3), East Harlem (Manhattan CD 11), Elmhurst/ Corona (Queens CD4), Jamaica (Queens CD 12), and Stapleton (Staten Island CD 1).    After the expression of interest/comment period, ACS will send a solicitation letter, describing the scope of services necessary for proposals from interested coalitions, to all who express interest in response to this notice.  In addition ACS will hold Community Partnership Initiative meetings in each of the 11 community districts. These meetings will be widely publicized, with the date set forth in both the solicitation letter and in a separate notice, and will be open to all community members and organizations. As this is a coalition approach, interested vendors are strongly encouraged to attend the meeting in their community, in order to engage other interested vendors and ask questions. During these meetings ACS will discuss the scope of services. Additionally, ACS will send the solicitation letter to anyone expressing interest at the meetings. Coalitions will have four weeks after their Community Partnership meeting to submit their proposals.   Vendors may contact Michael Walker at 212-341-3525 to be notified of Community Partnership meeting dates and obtain a copy of the solicitation letter.  ACS will rank all proposals received from each community coalition based on pre-determined criteria; the organizations that have submitted the proposal which is determined to be in the best interest of the City will be selected as the coalition for that community district. ACS will then negotiate and develop a complete strategic plan with that coalition and make any award.  ACS recognizes that it cannot launch all 11 demonstrations simultaneously.  Therefore, ACS plans to roll out the community partnership demonstrations in three stages:  the first will commence with the solicitation of proposals in approximately August 2006, the second in approximately December 2006, and the third in approximately January 2007.  Although these stages will be launched at different times, there will be a period where all coalitions will be working concurrently.  The approximate value of this procurement will be $1,650,000. Each community award will be for $150,000 and will run for twelve months from registration of the contract.  The estimated total duration of the Community Partnerships Initiative is 23 months, from August 2006 to June 2008.  This timeframe does not include evaluation.   ACS finds this procurement to be a demonstration project because the City has never delivered services via a coalition approach.  It is therefore in the Citys best interest to test and evaluate this proposed approach for feasibility and efficiency without a large commitment of resources.  ACS also finds this procurement to be innovative because of its selection process. The traditional selection approach for demonstration projects  is inadequate as outlined in the Procurement Policy Board (PPB) Rules section 3  11 (e-g) because no proposed vendor has been identified, there will be multiple awards from this procurement, and negotiations will be held only with vendors (in a coalition) who submit a proposal.  Incorporating a proposal selection process into this method is also innovative and will require all who wish to participate to develop or join a coalition, and submit a proposal.  This method will be evaluated to determine whether it is in the Citys interest to codify the method used into future PPB Rules.  Anyone interested in expressing comments on or submitting an expression of interest in this procurement may do so by writing to Michael Walker, Administration for Childrens Services, Office of Contracts, 150 William Street, 9th Floor, New York, NY 10038.  All statements of interest or comments must be received by 4 P.M., August 15, 2006.

The COMPASS-Elementary model is a robust design that caters to the whole child from Kindergarten through 5th grades. Beyond STEM, COMPASS programs strive to integrate literacy into all instruction; offers homework help, basic arts instruction and physical activity.
